Award.AwardTitle: MRI Acquisition of: Heavy-lift UAV Sensor Platform for Research and Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
With National Science Foundation support, Dr. Timothy Hare will use and make available to other researchers and engineers a heavy-lift unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV or drone) with multiple cameras and scanning sensors for a wide variety of uses in research and development. This combined UAV/remote sensing system makes possible rapid and accurate capture of environmental data for the creation of 3D models of vegetation, land surfaces, and constructed features. It also provides a platform for testing new robotic and remote sensing technologies. For instance, researchers in fields such as agricultural sciences and engineering technology can use the instrument for precision farming, farm and pasture mapping, and robotics development. Earth and space scientists can use the instrument for testing new sensors and environmental research. Dr. Hare will employ the vehicle to introduce new capabilities to Mesoamerican archaeology. Students will benefit from hands-on experience and development with cutting-edge technologies. This instrument will be the first one of its kind available to the researchers and students at Morehead State University, in Appalachian eastern Kentucky, and in Mesoamerican archaeological research.

The combined heavy-lift UAV/remote sensing system will enhance research and development by leveraging several new technologies. First, the heavy-lift UAV allows for carrying multiple sensors simultaneously at low elevations and slow speeds to capture high-resolution and overlapping image data through most climatic and surface conditions. Second, the global navigation satellite system and inertial measurement unit provide centimeter-level control and georeferencing of data. Third, the high-resolution cameras capture a variety of wavelengths including visible, near infrared, and infrared. Fourth, the Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) device can scan through vegetation with better than 10 cm accuracy. One example of the instrument's use is Dr. Hare's mapping of archaeological ruins and associated environmental features through the forest canopy for his ongoing archaeological investigations at the ancient city of Mayapán in the northern Yucatan of Mexico. The purpose of archaeological survey in Mexico's northern Yucatán Peninsula is to map the regional context of the ancient political and economic capital of Mayapán. Hence, the instrument will be used for archaeological field survey, mapping ancient settlements, and mapping excavations for spatial data analysis. The resulting data will make possible the creation of 3D models of ancient Mayan ruins at the scale of entire regions. Capturing material remains of past people in context is the foundation of all archaeological research, but these activities are hampered by difficult field conditions and the limitations and high costs of traditional mapping technologies. The combined heavy-lift UAV/remote sensing system will overcome these obstacles, making possible the creation of 3D maps of the ancient Mayan world at a detail level never before possible.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project allowed my institution to acquire an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV or drone) with integrated cameras, scanners, and a robotic arm to be used for improving research and teaching infrastructure for Morehead State University (MSU) and the region it serves. The UAV/sensors are being used to assist projects in archaeology, agriculture, and environmental science in eastern Kentucky. Use of the equipment includes faculty, staff, and students at MSU and community members in the region. The equipment acquisition will continue to impact training, research, and numerous applications in the future.

The acquired UAV and sensors incorporates four major technologies previously unavailable in the region:

    1.    A heavy-lift unmanned aerial vehicle capable of simultaneously carrying a wide variety of sensors to systematically capture many different data types for large areas at low elevations and slow speeds. The UAV is rugged and capable of handling hot and wet environmental conditions while carrying over 20 pounds of sensors for periods of more than 30 minutes of flight time.
    2.    A global navigation satellite system (GNSS) and inertial measurement unit (IMU) that can map the photos and laser scans from there UAV to an accuracy of less than an inch. 
    3.    A set of high-resolution cameras capable of capturing a variety of wavelengths including visible, near infrared, and infrared. The cameras can take photos using visible light as well as a variety of other wave lengths that scientists can use for studying the health and growth of vegetation and track animals at night and through dense forests.
    4.    A Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) device capable of scanning through vegetation. The LiDAR device can use lasers to penetrate forest cover and make maps and 3D models of the hidden terrain and other features.

The key to the success of this project is the integration of LiDAR and cameras into UAV systems for simultaneous recording of visible light, near-infrared, and topographical data. This combination of cutting-edge remote sensing technologies makes it possible to produce stunningly accurate and detailed maps and models of the landscape, fields, forests, or buildings.

The major accomplishments of the project thus far include:
    •    Acquisition of the heavy-lift UAV, a multispectral camera, a thermal camera, and a LiDAR device.
    •    Substantial training opportunities for students in all aspects of UAV construction, maintenance, piloting, data collection, and data analysis.
    •    Recruitment, training, and oversight of student and professional teams in the operation and use of the instrument.
    •    Development of an ongoing program for the collaborative research, development, and use of the instrument.
    •    Teaching teams of undergraduates and students in the Craft Academy (a public residential high school focusing on STEM education for gifted students) the underlying technology and how to use UAVs for remote sensing applications.
    •    Guiding teams of students and professionals, including groups of archaeologists in the use of UAVs for diverse purposes.

The most prominent projects currently using the instrument include archaeological investigations, precision agricultural activities, and monitoring of stream flow and erosion. The principal investigator (PI) is using the UAV/sensors as part of a strategy for photographing, mapping, and creating 3D models of archaeological ruins, excavations, caves, and landscapes.  The next task is to create a 3D model, through forest cover, of a late 18th century millstone quarry in central Kentucky. The PI is working with the MSU Agricultural Complex and a group of students  to map the entire farm topographically and use multispectral cameras to map vegetation growth. The PI and a group of students are periodically mapping the length of river in Rowan County Kentucky to monitor the effects of shoreline modifications on erosion and flooding.

The acquired UAV/sensor instrument is helping MSU fulfill its mission by providing enhanced opportunities and experiences using geospatial technologies including robotics, UAVs, GIS, GPS, GNSS, and remote sensing. This extends beyond the direct impact of the PI’s teaching, research, and mentoring roles to impact faculty and students in many positions across the institution and region. The training and involvement of students in projects impacted by this instrument will increase the participation of Appalachian students, including women and other under-represented groups, in science.
